Triggering Event: He saw her, his girlfriend of three years, laughing with their mutual friend at a café across the street from the hospital where he worked. The friend was a doctor, young, confident, successful. He felt his stomach twist as he realized she was holding the friend's hand, their fingers entwined in a way that seemed far too familiar for mere friendship.
Generated Assessment: She was laughing with him. She was smiling. I'm being paranoid. That doesn't mean anything. It means nothing. There's no reason to feel this way. Why am I feeling this way? She was just having fun. She had no intention of me seeing us together. I'm overreacting. I have no right to be upset. I don't know what it is about me that makes me think they're together. Maybe I'm just jealous of the attention he gives her. No, that can't be it. They were just friends. My feelings are irrational. I need to stop thinking like this. I must be imagining things. This isn't real. I'm just stressed out because of work. That's all there is to it. I'm fine. I'll get over it. She wouldn't really... Would she? This is ridiculous. What would happen if we actually did find ourselves together? Then what? I'd never forgive myself. I'd never look at myself in the mirror again. But that's impossible. We're not meant to be. I can't imagine why she would even want to hang out with him. He's not that special. I'm overthinking this. Nothing will come of it. She won't say anything. If I confront her, she'll deny everything. She wouldn't do something like that. I'm the one who needs to work on myself. This is all my fault. I'm just so insecure sometimes.

Triggering Event: An elderly woman, her eyes scanning the newspaper headlines she'd written decades ago, felt a pang of resentment as she noticed the younger staff's accolades displayed prominently nearby, while her own achievements were tucked away in the archives.
Generated Assessment: She was surprised by how much anger she felt when seeing these young people get all the credit for the company's latest success. It seemed like no matter what they did, it was always highlighted, but her contributions to the organization—years of dedication, hard work, and loyalty—were ignored. She wondered if this was some kind of conspiracy to make her feel like nothing mattered anymore. # This is where you would provide your analysis of the response. ## Analysis This response reflects the cognitive distortion "Should Statements" because the individual is attributing their emotions to an unwarranted expectation about how things "should" be. They seem to believe that the company should be recognizing their past contributions equally with the current successes of others, which isn't necessarily true. The response suggests an overemphasis on perceived injustices rather than accepting reality as it stands. By framing their feelings around expectations ("how angry I felt," "things should be"), the person is illustrating how often we unconsciously compare our experiences to internalized standards of what "should" happen. This tendency can lead us to misinterpret our emotions and create unnecessary tension. In this case, the person's reaction stems from their personal belief about fairness and recognition, rather than acknowledging the actual situation. In real-life scenarios, such reactions can manifest in various ways, including frustration, disappointment, or even anger towards others or oneself. Recognizing these patterns within ourselves can help us better understand our thoughts and emotions, ultimately leading to more balanced and rational

Triggering Event:
The email alert went off on his phone, a stark buzz against the quiet of his empty apartment. He picked it up, squinting at the sender's name: "Source - Confidential." His heart quickened as he tapped the screen to open it.

"Urgent: Meet me tomorrow, 8 AM, usual place. Have cash. It's about them," the message read.

His breath hitched as panic surged through him. The last time they'd met like this, his career had been on the line. Now, divorced and adrift, he couldn't afford another scandal. He typed out a reply, fingers trembling slightly, "I'll be there."
Generated Assessment: He didn't need this reminder that he was still in the shadow of his past mistakes. Every time he received a cryptic message like this, he felt like he was back in the trenches, fighting for every scrap of credibility. The worst part? No one else seemed to care how much his life had fallen apart after what happened with Rachel. They all just saw him as the guy who got fired for stealing from his clients. That wasn't fair, but it was the way things were now. So when he got this message, he knew exactly what it meant: more trouble waiting for him at the old warehouse. "I'm coming," he replied, already knowing the outcome would be disastrous.

Triggering Event: At 3 AM, retired officer John hears a faint creaking in his empty house. His breath catches as he remembers his late wife's footsteps echoing through their home years ago. Panic surges; it feels like she's there, but something's off. He reaches for his old service revolver, hand trembling. The creaking stops. Silence. Then, a sudden crash from the kitchen. John freezes, heart pounding. It's just an overturned trash can, but the panic remains, gripping him tightly.
Generated Assessment: It was probably my cat again. I could hear her meowing around midnight, and then I heard some stuff moving around in the kitchen. I assumed my wife must have been up making breakfast before she left for work. But now I'm worried about what might be happening when she’s away. Maybe someone is breaking into our house? Or maybe I’m just overreacting because we haven’t had any issues recently. It must be my mind playing tricks on me again. I've been feeling anxious lately with all these changes at work. And now this? It makes me wonder if everything will fall apart soon. What if someone really did break in? What if I accidentally locked myself out of my own house again? That would explain everything. I need to calm down, but why does it feel like everyone else has it together except me?

Triggering Event: She noticed it while grading papers at her kitchen table, the dim lighting casting long shadows across the room. A small, familiar handwriting in the margin of a student's essay, "You're not as smart as you think." Her heart pounded as she scanned the paper again, eyes darting to the window, then the door. She felt watched, her mind racing with who could have written such a thing. Could it be that new neighbor who'd been asking too many questions? Or was it one of her students, playing a cruel joke? She hugged herself tightly, eyes wide and alert in the suddenly hostile silence of her home.
Generated Assessment: She thought it was just an innocent comment from someone who didn't know better, but now that she's alone in her house, she can't shake off the feeling that there's something more sinister behind it. The words seem so personal, like someone is trying to make her doubt her own abilities. Why would anyone write something like that unless they were trying to hurt her?

Triggering Event: She noticed it while fact-checking her latest article - an email from his old news bureau address, sent three years after his death. The subject line was blank, the body empty except for a single date: tomorrow. Her breath caught in her throat as she felt the familiar pang of anxiety, her heart pounding like a drum roll heralding an uncertain storm.
Generated Assessment: She’s just so close to finishing this piece; I really need to focus now. It’s been a tough few days, but I can handle this. Tomorrow is going to be better than today. I’m ready for whatever comes next. I've got this. ## Conclusion: This response reflects the cognitive distortion by downplaying the significance of the triggering event, dismissing its potential impact on the writer's mental state. By focusing solely on the task at hand ("finishing this piece") and convincing themselves that "tomorrow will be better," the individual is attempting to avoid acknowledging the stress and anxiety associated with the unexpected message. This subtle dismissal of the event's implications illustrates how people often unconsciously discount positive experiences or events when faced with uncertainty or challenging situations, thereby perpetuating the distorted thinking pattern. # Example Response She’s just so close to finishing this piece; I really need to focus now. Triggering Event: A man, nearing 60, walks into his favorite dive bar after another grueling day on the job. The bartender slides him his usual drink, but tonight there's a smudge of dirt on the glass. He feels his gut twist, his hatred for such sloppiness bubbling up. As he wipes it off himself, he notices the regulars laughing loudly at a worn-out joke, one he's told countless times before. His hand clenches around the glass, his hate for their insensitivity and disrespect for his hard-earned patience surging like a bitter tide.
Generated Assessment: Ahh, this place is just full of ungrateful bums these days. I'm going to tell them how it feels to have to clean your dirty glasses every single time you come in here. They don't deserve a free ride because they're too lazy to wipe themselves down after drinking all night. This place needs to be shut down anyway; the owner must be getting some shady money from these freeloaders. I'll report this place for the health code violations right now. And while I'm at it, I'm going to complain about my work schedule to the manager again and see if he can get me a raise for dealing with such horrible people.

Triggering Event: In the quiet of her kitchen, she watches him stir his coffee for what feels like an eternity, each spoon clink echoing her growing unease. He's been distant lately, his usual morning hum replaced by a heavy silence that presses against her chest like an unyielding weight. She wonders if he even notices her there, or if she's just another piece of furniture in their once warm, now cooling home. Today is their anniversary, but the card she bought him still lies unopened on the counter, gathering dust alongside her fading hopes for a romantic breakfast. Instead, they'll likely share another silent meal, each lost in their own thoughts, their connection growing more tenuous with every passing moment.
Generated Assessment: She can't shake off the feeling that something is terribly wrong, even though she knows he's fine, he has nothing to be anxious about. The fact that he didn't mention it, that he hasn't mentioned anything at all, makes her think he's hiding something. It's probably nothing, but she can't help but imagine the worst-case scenarios. Maybe he doesn't want to talk about it? Or maybe he's already made up his mind and won't change it. She tries to remind herself that people are different, and some just need time to open up, but deep down, she fears she might lose him forever.

Triggering Event: Driving home from a late shift, she noticed him - her ex-husband, now married to someone else, walking hand in hand with his wife and their child. Their laughter echoed down the street, grating against her weary ears like nails on chalkboard. She felt the familiar pang of resentment in her chest, a bitter taste rising in her mouth as she gripped the steering wheel tighter, knuckles white.
Generated Assessment: She's just so toxic, always been that way, even when they were together. He was lucky to get away from her once he found someone who could actually handle him. Now he's probably still getting into trouble with his new wife, I wouldn't be surprised if she turns out to be another gold-digger like all the rest. They're probably having kids too, so there's no chance he'll ever come back to me.

Triggering Event:
Scenario:

She sat at her lab bench, squinting through her magnifying glasses at the stubborn sample under her microscope. Her partner had promised to drop off lunch hours ago, but there was no sign of them or their meal. She sighed, pushing away from the bench and picking up her phone to check for messages. Nothing. Frustration gnawed at her as she looked back at the sample, unchanged despite her meticulous work.
Generated Assessment: She always has this problem with food; I swear, it’s never going to change. My lab is just too quiet sometimes, and my brain goes to weird places when there’s nothing else to focus on. Like, what if they’re avoiding me? Or worse, what if something happened that I don’t know about? It feels like every time I look for answers, I’m left more confused than ever. # Response End
